chapter.title: Installing Ahven
chapter.para: To build and install Ahven source code, you need an Ada 95 compiler. At the moment, Ahven is tested with three different compiler families: GNAT, ObjectAda, and Janus/Ada.

sect2.title: GNAT GPL series and FSF GCC
sect2.para: When you have GNAT GPL or FSF GCC, the easieast way to compile and install Ahven is to use the make utility and Makefile.

When compiling using the make utility, you need to tell your platform type. Currently, only supported platform types are unix and windows. The type can be told by setting OS_VERSION variable to the selected platform. $ make OS_VERSION=unix

If you are unable to use make, you can use the GNAT project files directly. Ahven distribution comes with three GNAT project files: ahven.gpr, ahven_lib.gpr, and ahven_tests.gpr. The ahven.gpr file is meant to be used when compiling unit tests. The library itself is build using the ahven_lib.gpr file. To build the testsuite of the Ahven, one needs to use the ahven_tests.gpr file.

Like with Makefile, you need to tell your platform type. This time the selection happens by using an environment variable called OS. The variable accepts same values as Makefile. $ OS=windows gnatmake -P ahven_lib $ OS=windows gnatmake -P ahven_tests

sect2.title: Installing Library
sect2.para: You can install the library by using command make install. By default the installation happens to the /usr/local directory. Alternative directory can be set by overwriting the PREFIX variable. $ make OS_VERSION=unix PREFIX=/opt/ada install

sect1.title: GNAT 3.15p
sect1.para: Version 3.15p of GNAT does not understand some features used in the default GNAT project files. Therefore, you need to use project files from the contrib/gnat315p directory.

sect1.title: ObjectAda
sect1.para: There is no project file included for ObjectAda. To compile Ahven, you need to create a new project and import the source code of Ahven to the project.

sect1.title: Janus/Ada
sect1.para: Directory janusada contains project file creation scripts for Janus/Ada. By default, the scripts assume Janus/Ada to be installed to directory C:\Janus312\. If that is not the case, change the path from files pr_lib.bat and pr_test.bat.

Before doing anything else, you need to copy file libmain.adb from janusada to src. Then, you create the project file by running pr_lib.bat in the src directory. C:\ahven-1.4\src>..\janusada\pr_lib.bat

After creating the project file, you need to use COrder to create the compilation script. This happens by running makelib.bat. C:\ahven-1.4\src>..\janusada\makelib.bat At one point, COrder requires you to specify the location of Ahven.Compat body. Give it a file windows\ahven-compat.adb.
Now, you can compile the library using script ctst.bat.
To compile the test suite for Ahven, you need to run pr_test.bat and maketest.bat scripts in the test directory. C:\ahven-1.4\test>..\janusada\pr_test.bat C:\ahven-1.4\test>..\janusada\maketest.bat

Again, COrder should create you a script called ctst.bat. Use it to compile the source code. To link the object code into a single executable, go to the test_objects directory and type lkc tester. The command should produce tester.exe, which you can run.
